title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
2 Points

  • 1 point (i) MR=MC for output

  • 1 point (ii) P from demand curve
descriptions:
The student earns none of the following points:

  • 1 point (i) MR=MC for output

  • 1 point (ii) P from demand curve

The student earns one of the following points:

  • 1 point (i) MR=MC for output

  • 1 point (ii) P from demand curve

The student earns all of the following points:

  • 1 point (i) MR=MC for output

  • 1 point (ii) P from demand curve

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
2 Points

  • 1 point (i) Q1 and P5 (or Point B)

  • 1 point (ii) A to D (or range for which MR > 0)

It is not necessary for them to acknowledge that D technically shouldn't be included in this line segment.

While other line segments (AB, AC, BC, BD, CD) are elastic, they include only a portion of the line segment that elastic and should not be given credit.
descriptions:

  • 1 point (ii) A to D (or range for which MR > 0)

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 Point

  • 1 point Q2 and P4 (or point C)
descriptions:
The student earns none of the following points:

  • 1 point Q2 and P4 (or point C)

The student earns all of the following points:

  • 1 point Q2 and P4 (or point C)

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
2 Points

  • 1 point (i) ABP5 (monopoly)

If the answer to (d)(i) is incorrect but consistent with the student's answer in (b), credit should be given.

  • 1 point (ii) ACP4 (perfect competition)

Again, there is a consistency problem; if the answer to (ii) is incorrect but is consistent with the (incorrect) answer the student gave in part (c), credit should be given.
descriptions:

  • 1 point (i) ABP5 (monopoly)

If the answer to (d)(i) is incorrect but consistent with the student's answer in (b), credit should be given.

  • 1 point (ii) ACP4 (perfect competition)

Again, there is a consistency problem; if the answer to (ii) is incorrect but is consistent with the (incorrect) answer the student gave in part (c), credit should be given.

The student earns one of the following points:

  • 1 point (i) ABP5 (monopoly)

If the answer to (d)(i) is incorrect but consistent with the student's answer in (b), credit should be given.

  • 1 point (ii) ACP4 (perfect competition)

Again, there is a consistency problem; if the answer to (ii) is incorrect but is consistent with the (incorrect) answer the student gave in part (c), credit should be given.

The student earns all of the following points:

  • 1 point (i) ABP5 (monopoly)

If the answer to (d)(i) is incorrect but consistent with the student's answer in (b), credit should be given.

  • 1 point (ii) ACP4 (perfect competition)

Again, there is a consistency problem; if the answer to (ii) is incorrect but is consistent with the (incorrect) answer the student gave in part (c), credit should be given.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml:
1 Point

  • 1 point P = MC, or MB = MC

This definition is entirely self-contained; there need be no reference to the graph to get full credit.
descriptions:
The student earns none of the following points:

  • 1 point P = MC, or MB = MC

This definition is entirely self-contained; there need be no reference to the graph to get full credit.

The student earns all of the following points:

  • 1 point P = MC, or MB = MC

This definition is entirely self-contained; there need be no reference to the graph to get full credit.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml:
1 Point

  • 1 point Q2

If this answer is incorrect, the student receives no credit even if it is consistent with part (e)
descriptions:
The student earns none of the following points:

  • 1 point Q2

If this answer is incorrect, the student receives no credit even if it is consistent with part (e)

The student earns all of the following points:

  • 1 point Q2

If this answer is incorrect, the student receives no credit even if it is consistent with part (e)

title: Part G
stimulusHtml:
2 Points

  • 1 point: (i)A per-unit subsidy. Merely the word "subsidy" is sufficient.

  • 1 point: (ii)An explanation that the subsidy either

    1. lowers MC, or

    2. raises MR, or

    3. shifts the demand curve out

A statement that output increases is not sufficient.
